sn18.1:1.3: Rāhula was the Buddha’s son to his wife Bhaddakaccānā (AN 1.245). Rāhula’s going forth is related at Kd 1:54.1.1, and other important discourses with him include MN 61, MN 62, and MN 147 = SN 35.121. In the latter he became an arahant, which he confirmed in his own words at Thag 4.8. Commentaries explain his name as meaning “bondage”, but it probably refers rather to being born under the influence of the dark star Rāhu (SN 2.8). The Buddha declared him the foremost of monks who desire training (AN 1.209). This is illustrated in this series of lessons through which Rāhula doggedly persists. His death is not noted in the early texts.
sn18.1:4.1: In this and similar passages, Mahāsaṅgīti edition inserts unnecessary ellipses.
